note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
John Jones Pettus belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Winston County, Louisville was founded as early as 1836 and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

gloss.p: "A factory where strong alcoholic drinks are produced by the process of distilling." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Events -- Natural & Human Caused Disasters

gloss.p: "The state of having no food for a long period, often causing death." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An official organization whose job is to manage a particular activity, suggest laws related to the activity, and make certain that laws are obeyed" concerning law enforcement. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
A court of law for "the legal process of deciding if a person's will has been made correctly and if the information it contains is correct." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Mississippi State Legislature (originally called the "General Assembly") was established by Article 4 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890, and serves as the legislative branch of the state government. It is comprised of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Legislature is responsible for passing new statewide laws and making amendments to the Constitution. (Wikipedia)

div.p: To his Excellency, John. J. Pettus

The undersigned, President & Members of the Bourd of Police of Winston County being now in open Session respectfully repre-sent to your Excellency that they have heard with regret that appli-cation from this County has been, or will be made to your Excellency to secure the privilege, in contra=vention of our late Leg=islature, to distill ardent Spirits.

Your petitioners have learned that for this purpose a petition, somewhat numerously signed, has been procured by interested parties, which might induce your Excellency to suppose that the people of this county desired the granting of such application. [gap] The Board of Police representing every portion of the county, & perfectly familiar with the wants wishes of its people, take this occasion to assure your Excel-
Petition of Board of Police Winston County. Against distilliation of grains in their County
-lency that the people of Winston desire & pray your Excellency to refuse any, & all such application.

The Board of Police assure the Govr. that there is not in this County one half of the corn necessary to feed the population; & but for the supplies of bread obtained from the Prairies east of this County there would be an amount of suffering beyond all forever precedent.
Your petitioners ask that if any such licence has been granted that your Excellency will revoke it, & also refuse sanction to any such applica-tion if any is made.

S. B. Crow President P,, T
John C Humphries
Jared Richardson
A. Gillis

I E D Hyde Clerk of Probate Court & Board of Police of said County, do hereby certify that the manes to the foregoing petition or memorial are genuine signature, that the same was done in open court on the day of the date there of In testimony whereof I have hereunto set my honor seal of said court at this office this 20th day of January A.D. 1863 [gap] —E. D. Hyde Clerk
